articles.title: Mortgages and AI to be added to the curriculum in English schools
articles.summary: Ministers are making the changes for children in England after a review of what is taught in schools.
articles.content:
Mortgages and AI to be added to the curriculum in English schools

6 hours ago Share Save Share Save

Getty Images

Children will be taught how to budget and how mortgages work as the government seeks to modernise the national curriculum in England's schools. They will also be taught how to spot fake news and disinformation, including AI-generated content, following the first review of what is taught in schools in over a decade. Education Secretary Bridget Phillipson said the government wanted to "revitalise" the curriculum but keep a "firm foundation" in basics like English, maths and reading. Head teachers said the review's recommendations were "sensible" but would require "sufficient funding and teachers".

The government commissioned a review of the national curriculum and assessments in England last year, in the hope of developing a "cutting edge" curriculum that would narrow attainment gaps between the most disadvantaged students and their classmates. It said it would take up most of the review's recommendations, including scrapping the English Baccalaureate (EBacc), a progress measure for schools introduced in 2010. It assesses schools based on how many pupils take English, maths, sciences, geography or history and a language - and how well they do. The Department for Education (DfE) said the EBacc was "constraining", and that removing it alongside reforms to another school ranking system, Progress 8, would "encourage students to study a greater breadth of GCSE subjects", like arts. The former Conservative schools minister, Nick Gibb, said the decision to scrap the EBacc would "lead to a precipitous decline in the study of foreign languages", which he said would become increasingly centred on private schools and "children of middle class parents who can afford tutors". Other reforms coming as a result of the curriculum review include: Financial literacy being taught in maths classes, or compulsory citizenship lessons in primary schools

More focus on spotting misinformation and disinformation - including exploring a new post-16 qualification in data science and AI

Cutting time spent on GCSE exams by up to three hours for each student on average

Ensuring all children can take three science GCSEs

More content on climate change

Better representation of diversity The review also recommended giving oracy the same status in the curriculum as reading and writing, which the charity Voice 21 said was a "vital step forward" for teaching children valuable speaking, listening, and communication skills.

However, the government is not taking up all of the review's recommendations. It is pushing ahead with the reading tests for Year 8 pupils reported in September, whereas the review recommended compulsory English and maths tests for that year group. Asked why she stopped short of taking up the review's recommendation, Phillipson told the BBC that pupils who are unable to read "fluently and confidently" often struggle in other subjects. And she addressed the claims that scrapping the EBacc could lead to fewer pupils taking history, geography and languages at GCSE, saying the measure "hasn't led to improved outcomes" or "improvement in language study". "I want young people to have a good range of options, including subjects like art and music and sport. And I know that's what parents want as well," she said. She said ministers recognised "the need to implement this carefully, thoroughly and with good notice", adding that schools would have four terms of notice before being expected to teach the new curriculum.

Prof Becky Francis, who chaired the review, said her panel of experts and the government had both identified a "problem" pupils experience during the first years of secondary school. "When young people progress from primary into secondary school, typically this is a time when their learning can start falling behind, and that's particularly the case for kids from socially disadvantaged backgrounds," she told the BBC.

Professor Becky Francis led the curriculum and assessment review

The article provides sufficient detail on the reforms and their intended impact, making it a substantive and meaningful educational improvement.
articles.personality_title: England updates school curriculum with mortgages, AI, and fake news lessons
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – England’s government has reviewed the school curriculum for the first time in over ten years. They wanted to make lessons more relevant to today’s world and help students learn skills useful for their future.

**What happened** – New topics like how mortgages work, budgeting money, and spotting fake news and AI-generated false information will be taught in schools. The government will also add lessons on data science and artificial intelligence (AI), financial literacy in math classes, and more focus on climate change and diversity. They plan to remove some older rules like the English Baccalaureate (EBacc), which limited the range of subjects students could study.

**Impact** – These changes will give students practical knowledge about money and technology, helping them understand real-life challenges. Teaching how to spot misinformation is especially important in today’s digital world. The reforms also aim to support students who struggle after moving to secondary school, including those from less advantaged backgrounds. However, some worry that removing the EBacc might reduce the number of students learning languages and history.

**What's next step** – Schools will have four terms to prepare before the new curriculum starts. The government will continue to adjust tests and assessments, making some exams shorter and ensuring all students can take three science courses. They will also watch how these changes affect students’ learning and make improvements if needed.

**One-sentence takeaway** – England’s schools will soon teach practical money skills, modern technology topics, and critical thinking to better prepare students for today’s world and future challenges.
articles.personality_title_fr: L’Angleterre modernise son programme scolaire avec des cours sur les prêts immobiliers, l’IA et les fausses informations
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Le gouvernement anglais a revu le programme scolaire pour la première fois depuis plus de dix ans. Il voulait rendre les cours plus adaptés au monde d’aujourd’hui et aider les élèves à acquérir des compétences utiles pour leur avenir.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – De nouveaux sujets comme le fonctionnement des prêts immobiliers, la gestion de budget et la détection des fausses informations générées par l’IA seront enseignés dans les écoles. Le gouvernement ajoutera aussi des cours sur la science des données et l’intelligence artificielle (IA), la littératie financière en mathématiques, ainsi qu’un accent plus fort sur le changement climatique et la diversité. Ils prévoient de supprimer certaines règles anciennes comme le Baccalauréat anglais (EBacc), qui limitait le choix des matières.

**Impact** – Ces changements offriront aux élèves des connaissances pratiques sur l’argent et la technologie, les aidant à mieux comprendre les défis de la vie réelle. Apprendre à repérer la désinformation est particulièrement important à l’ère numérique. Les réformes visent aussi à soutenir les élèves en difficulté après le passage au collège, notamment ceux issus de milieux défavorisés. Cependant, certains craignent que la suppression de l’EBacc réduise le nombre d’élèves étudiant les langues et l’histoire.

**Prochaine étape** – Les écoles disposeront de quatre trimestres pour se préparer avant la mise en place du nouveau programme. Le gouvernement continuera d’ajuster les tests et examens, en raccourcissant certains et en garantissant que tous les élèves puissent passer trois cours de sciences. Ils surveilleront aussi l’impact de ces changements pour améliorer si nécessaire.

**En une phrase** – Les écoles anglaises enseigneront bientôt des compétences pratiques en argent, des sujets modernes sur la technologie et la pensée critique pour mieux préparer les élèves au monde actuel et à ses défis.
articles.personality_title_es: Inglaterra actualiza el currículo escolar con lecciones sobre hipotecas, IA y noticias falsas
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – El gobierno de Inglaterra revisó el currículo escolar por primera vez en más de diez años. Quería hacer las clases más relevantes para el mundo actual y ayudar a los estudiantes a aprender habilidades útiles para su futuro.

**Qué pasó** – Se enseñarán nuevos temas como cómo funcionan las hipotecas, cómo manejar un presupuesto y cómo detectar noticias falsas y desinformación generada por inteligencia artificial (IA). También se agregarán lecciones sobre ciencia de datos e IA, educación financiera en las clases de matemáticas y más enfoque en el cambio climático y la diversidad. Se planea eliminar algunas reglas antiguas como el Bachillerato Inglés (EBacc), que limitaba la variedad de materias que los estudiantes podían estudiar.

**Impacto** – Estos cambios darán a los estudiantes conocimientos prácticos sobre dinero y tecnología, ayudándolos a entender mejor los desafíos reales. Aprender a detectar la desinformación es muy importante en el mundo digital de hoy. Las reformas también buscan apoyar a los estudiantes que tienen dificultades al pasar a la escuela secundaria, incluidos aquellos de entornos menos favorecidos. Sin embargo, algunos temen que eliminar el EBacc reduzca el número de estudiantes que estudian idiomas e historia.

**Próximo paso** – Las escuelas tendrán cuatro trimestres para prepararse antes de que comience el nuevo currículo. El gobierno seguirá ajustando pruebas y exámenes, reduciendo algunos y asegurando que todos los estudiantes puedan tomar tres cursos de ciencias. También vigilarán cómo afectan estos cambios al aprendizaje para hacer mejoras si es necesario.

**Conclusión en una frase** – Las escuelas de Inglaterra enseñarán pronto habilidades prácticas de dinero, temas modernos de tecnología y pensamiento crítico para preparar mejor a los estudiantes para el mundo actual y sus desafíos.

articles.title: 5,500-year-old site in Jordan reveals a lost civilization’s secrets
articles.summary: After the collapse of the Chalcolithic culture around 3500 BCE, people in Jordan’s Murayghat transformed their way of life, shifting from domestic settlements to ritual landscapes filled with dolmens, standing stones, and megalithic monuments. Archaeologists from the University of Copenhagen believe these changes reflected a creative social response to climate and societal upheaval.
articles.content:
How did early civilizations respond when their worlds fell apart? Archaeologists from the University of Copenhagen believe the 5,000-year-old site of Murayghat in Jordan may reveal some clues. Their extensive excavations suggest that this Early Bronze Age community developed powerful new traditions in the aftermath of cultural collapse.

Murayghat rose to prominence after the decline of the Chalcolithic culture (ca. 4500-3500 BCE), an era known for its village settlements, symbolic art, copper tools, and small shrines used for worship. According to researchers, a combination of climate change and social upheaval likely contributed to the collapse of that earlier way of life.

In the wake of this disruption, communities of the Early Bronze Age appear to have reimagined how they expressed faith and identity.

"Instead of the large domestic settlements with smaller shrines established during the Chalcolithic, our excavations at Early Bronze Age Murayghat show clusters of dolmens (stone burial monuments), standing stones, and large megalithic structures that point to ritual gatherings and communal burials rather than living quarters," explains project leader and archaeologist Susanne Kerner of the University of Copenhagen.

Symbols of Identity and Territory

Archaeologists have documented more than 95 dolmen structures at Murayghat. The hilltop area at the center of the site also includes stone enclosures and carved rock features that appear to have had ceremonial purposes.

These striking monuments may have served as territorial markers or social symbols during a time when no central authority held power. Kerner notes, "Murayghat gives us, we believe, fascinating new insights into how early societies coped with disruption by building monuments, redefining social roles, and creating new forms of community."

Rituals, Feasts, and Community Gathering

Excavations have uncovered a variety of artifacts that further support the idea of ritual activity at the site. Researchers found Early Bronze Age pottery, large communal bowls, grinding stones, flint tools, animal horn cores, and a few copper objects -- all items that suggest ceremonial use and possible feasting events.

The layout and visibility of Murayghat also indicate that it may have served as a regional meeting place where different groups came together for social or spiritual gatherings.

Kerner recently detailed these findings in her publication Dolmens, standing stones and ritual in Murayghat, featured in the journal Levant. Her team's work is helping reveal how ancient societies transformed crisis into creativity -- building enduring symbols of identity and community that still stand amid the Jordanian hills today.
articles.reasoning: The article reports on a significant archaeological discovery that reveals how ancient societies creatively responded to climate and social upheaval by transforming their cultural practices. This insight into human resilience and adaptation has broad cultural and historical significance, offering meaningful knowledge about early civilizations and their social innovations.
articles.personality_title: Ancient Jordan site reveals how early people rebuilt community after crisis
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Around 5,500 years ago, people living in what is now Jordan faced big changes. The Chalcolithic culture, known for village life and copper tools, collapsed due to climate and social troubles.

**What happened** – Archaeologists from the University of Copenhagen studied a site called Murayghat in Jordan. They found many stone monuments like dolmens (burial stones), standing stones, and large megaliths. Instead of homes, these showed places for rituals and group burials. They also found pottery and tools that suggest people gathered for ceremonies and feasts.

**Impact** – This discovery shows that after their old way of life ended, these early people created new traditions to express their identity and faith. They built big monuments to mark territory and bring communities together without a central leader. This helps us understand how people can adapt to hard times by changing how they live and connect.

**What's next step** – Researchers will keep studying Murayghat and similar sites to learn more about ancient social changes. These findings could change how historians see early human societies and their ability to face challenges.

**One-sentence takeaway** – The Murayghat site reveals how ancient people in Jordan transformed their culture through monuments and rituals after a major collapse, showing early social creativity and resilience.
articles.personality_title_fr: Un site ancien en Jordanie révèle comment les premiers habitants ont reconstruit leur communauté après une crise
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Il y a environ 5 500 ans, les habitants de l'actuelle Jordanie ont connu de grands changements. La culture chalcolithique, connue pour ses villages et ses outils en cuivre, s'est effondrée à cause du climat et de problèmes sociaux.

**Ce qui s'est passé** – Des archéologues de l'Université de Copenhague ont étudié un site appelé Murayghat en Jordanie. Ils ont trouvé de nombreux monuments en pierre comme des dolmens (pierres funéraires), des pierres dressées et de grandes constructions mégalithiques. Au lieu de maisons, ces sites montraient des lieux de rituels et d'enterrements collectifs. Ils ont aussi découvert de la poterie et des outils qui suggèrent des rassemblements pour des cérémonies et des festins.

**Impact** – Cette découverte montre qu'après la fin de leur ancienne façon de vivre, ces premiers habitants ont créé de nouvelles traditions pour exprimer leur identité et leur foi. Ils ont construit de grands monuments pour marquer leur territoire et rassembler les communautés sans chef central. Cela nous aide à comprendre comment les gens peuvent s'adapter aux moments difficiles en changeant leur mode de vie et leurs liens sociaux.

**Prochaine étape** – Les chercheurs vont continuer d'étudier Murayghat et des sites similaires pour en apprendre plus sur les changements sociaux anciens. Ces découvertes pourraient modifier la façon dont les historiens voient les premières sociétés humaines et leur capacité à faire face aux défis.

**Résumé en une phrase** – Le site de Murayghat révèle comment les anciens habitants de Jordanie ont transformé leur culture par des monuments et des rituels après un effondrement majeur, montrant créativité sociale et résilience précoces.
articles.personality_title_es: Sitio antiguo en Jordania revela cómo los primeros pueblos reconstruyeron su comunidad tras una crisis
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Hace unos 5,500 años, las personas que vivían en lo que hoy es Jordania enfrentaron grandes cambios. La cultura calcolítica, conocida por sus aldeas y herramientas de cobre, colapsó debido a problemas climáticos y sociales.

**Qué pasó** – Arqueólogos de la Universidad de Copenhague estudiaron un sitio llamado Murayghat en Jordania. Encontraron muchos monumentos de piedra como dólmenes (piedras para entierros), piedras erguidas y grandes megalitos. En lugar de casas, estos lugares mostraban sitios para rituales y entierros grupales. También hallaron cerámica y herramientas que sugieren que la gente se reunía para ceremonias y fiestas.

**Impacto** – Este descubrimiento muestra que, después de que su antigua forma de vida terminó, estas primeras personas crearon nuevas tradiciones para expresar su identidad y fe. Construyeron grandes monumentos para marcar territorio y unir a las comunidades sin un líder central. Esto nos ayuda a entender cómo las personas pueden adaptarse a tiempos difíciles cambiando su forma de vivir y relacionarse.

**Próximo paso** – Los investigadores seguirán estudiando Murayghat y sitios similares para aprender más sobre los cambios sociales antiguos. Estos hallazgos podrían cambiar cómo los historiadores ven a las primeras sociedades humanas y su capacidad para enfrentar desafíos.

**Resumen en una frase** – El sitio de Murayghat revela cómo las antiguas personas en Jordania transformaron su cultura mediante monumentos y rituales después de un colapso importante, mostrando creatividad social y resiliencia tempranas.
